topics.title: Introduction to Projectile Motion
key_concepts: Projectile motion combines constant horizontal velocity with uniformly accelerated vertical motion (gravity).
Horizontal and vertical motions are independent (neglecting air resistance).
Trajectory of a projectile (under constant g) is a parabola.

important_terms.definition: An object in free flight affected only by gravity (neglecting air resistance).
The curved path traced by a projectile through space.
Angle between the initial velocity vector and the horizontal.

topics.summary: Projectile motion is modeled by separating motion into horizontal (constant velocity) and vertical (constant acceleration g) components. Combining solutions yields a parabolic trajectory described by kinematic equations.

topics.title: Kinematic Equations and Component Analysis
key_concepts: Resolve initial velocity v0 into v0x = v0 cosθ and v0y = v0 sinθ.
Horizontal motion: x = v0x t (no horizontal acceleration).
Vertical motion: y = v0y t - (1/2) g t^2 and vy = v0y - g t.

important_terms.definition: Components of the initial velocity in horizontal and vertical directions.
Total time the projectile remains in motion before returning to the reference vertical level.
The highest vertical position reached, where vertical velocity equals zero.

topics.summary: Use vector decomposition to apply 1D kinematic formulas independently to horizontal and vertical axes. Solve for time, position, and velocities using v0x, v0y, and g.

topics.title: Range, Maximum Height, and Optimization
key_concepts: Maximum range for given speed occurs at θ = 45° (neglecting air resistance).

important_terms.definition: Horizontal distance traveled by a projectile between launch and landing at same vertical level.
The launch angle that maximizes range for a given speed, typically 45° without air resistance.
For level launches, the ascent and descent times are equal; speed at equal heights are equal in magnitude.

topics.summary: Key derived formulas: R = (v0^2 sin(2θ))/g, H = (v0^2 sin^2 θ)/(2g). Use these to optimize launch parameters and compute peak and distance properties.

topics.title: Extensions: Angled Launches, Heights, and Limitations
key_concepts: For launch from height h, time of flight solves quadratic y(t) = h + v0y t - 0.5 g t^2 = 0 for t>0.
Inclined-plane and moving-observer problems require coordinate rotation or relative velocity.
Air resistance invalidates simple independence and typically reduces range and alters symmetry.

important_terms.definition: Projectile released from nonzero initial height; landing time found by solving vertical position equation for t.
Analysis of projectile trajectories observed from moving frames; velocities add vectorially.
A force opposing motion; makes equations nonlinear and often requires numerical methods.

topics.summary: Realistic problems may include nonzero launch heights, inclined targets, moving observers, or drag. These require modified equations or numerical solutions; basic projectile results apply when drag is negligible.

questions.question_text: At what angle above horizontal is the range of a projectile maximized (neglecting air resistance)?
questions.explanation: Range R = (v0^2 sin(2θ))/g is maximized when sin(2θ)=1, so 2θ = 90°, θ = 45°.

questions.question_text: Explain why horizontal motion and vertical motion are treated independently in projectile problems (neglecting air resistance).
questions.correct_answer: Because gravity acts vertically only, so horizontal acceleration is zero and vertical acceleration is g; thus motions obey independent kinematic equations.
questions.explanation: Newton's second law gives no horizontal force (zero acceleration) while vertical acceleration is constant g, allowing separate 1D analyses.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched with speed 20 m/s at 30 degrees. What are the horizontal and vertical components of the initial velocity?
questions.explanation: Compute v0x = v0 cosθ and v0y = v0 sinθ. cos30°≈0.866, sin30°=0.5.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched from ground level with speed 25 m/s at 40°. Calculate the time of flight (use g = 9.8 m/s^2).
questions.explanation: Time of flight = 2 v0 sinθ / g = 2(25)(sin40°)/9.8 ≈ 3.21 s.

questions.question_text: Using the same projectile (25 m/s at 40°), find the maximum height reached.
Find the horizontal range for the projectile launched at 25 m/s and 40° (g = 9.8 m/s^2).
A projectile is launched horizontally from a cliff 45 m high with initial horizontal speed 15 m/s. How far from the cliff base does it land?
questions.explanation: Time to fall t = sqrt(2h/g) = sqrt(90/9.8)=3.03 s. Horizontal distance = v0x * t = 15*3.03 ≈ 45.9 m.

questions.question_text: Which factor causes the symmetry between ascent and descent to break for a projectile?
questions.explanation: Air resistance produces a non-conservative force that changes the speed differently during ascent and descent, breaking symmetry.

questions.question_text: A student claims that doubling the launch speed doubles the range for a fixed angle. Is the claim correct? Explain briefly.
questions.correct_answer: No. Range scales with v0^2, so doubling v0 quadruples the range for the same angle (R ∝ v0^2).
questions.explanation: R = (v0^2 sin2θ)/g shows quadratic dependence on v0, not linear.

questions.question_text: A projectile is launched at speed 30 m/s from a height of 10 m at angle 50°. Compute the time to impact (use g = 9.8 m/s^2).
questions.explanation: Solve y(t)=h + v0y t - 0.5 g t^2 = 0 with v0y=30 sin50°≈22.98 m/s:  -4.9 t^2 + 22.98 t +10 =0 → positive root t≈3.06 s.

questions.question_text: Describe briefly how you would analyze a projectile on an inclined plane.
questions.correct_answer: Rotate axes to align one axis parallel to the incline; decompose initial velocity into components along and perpendicular to incline; apply kinematics along incline and solve for intersection.
questions.explanation: Using rotated coordinates simplifies the geometry; treat motion along incline with appropriate acceleration components.
